triples.sentence: Humans are one of the most [adaptable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptation "Adaptation") species, despite having a low or narrow tolerance for many of the earth's extreme environments.[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Piantadosi-2003-133)
triples.statement: Humans are a highly adaptable species, even though they have a low tolerance for many of Earth's extreme environments.

triples.sentence: Currently the species is present in all eight [biogeographical realms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biogeographical_realms "Biogeographical realms"), although their presence in the [Antarctic realm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antarctic_realm "Antarctic realm") is very limited to [research stations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_stations_in_Antarctica "Research stations in Antarctica") and annually there is a population decline in the winter months of this realm.[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-134)
triples.statement: Humans are present in all eight biogeographical realms, though their presence in the Antarctic realm is limited to research stations and declines in winter.

triples.sentence: Humans [have visited](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exploration_of_the_Moon "Exploration of the Moon") the [Moon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon "Moon") and made their presence known on other [celestial bodies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celestial_bodies "Celestial bodies") through human-made [robotic spacecraft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_spacecraft "Robotic spacecraft").[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-136)[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-137)[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-138)
triples.statement: Humans have visited the Moon and have explored other celestial bodies using robotic spacecraft.

triples.sentence: Since 2000, there has been continuous human presence [in space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_presence_in_space "Human presence in space") through habitation on the [International Space Station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Space_Station "International Space Station").[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-139)
triples.statement: Since 2000, humans have maintained a continuous presence in space aboard the International Space Station.

triples.sentence: By using advanced tools and [clothing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clothing "Clothing"), humans have been able to extend their tolerance to a wide variety of temperatures, [humidities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humidity "Humidity"), and altitudes.[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Piantadosi-2003-133)[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-140)
triples.statement: Advanced tools and clothing have allowed humans to extend their tolerance to a wide range of temperatures, humidities, and altitudes.

triples.sentence: As a result, humans are a [cosmopolitan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmopolitan_distribution "Cosmopolitan distribution") species found in almost all regions of the world, including [tropical rainforest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropical_rainforest "Tropical rainforest"), [arid desert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desert "Desert"), extremely cold [arctic regions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arctic_region "Arctic region"), and heavily polluted cities; in comparison, most other species are confined to a few geographical areas by their limited adaptability.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-141)
triples.statement: Humans are a cosmopolitan species found in nearly all regions of the world, from tropical rainforests to arctic regions, unlike most other species which are geographically confined by their adaptability.

triples.sentence: The [human population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_population "Human population") is not, however, uniformly distributed on the [Earth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earth "Earth")'s surface, because the population density varies from one region to another, and large stretches of surface are almost completely uninhabited, like [Antarctica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica") and vast swathes of the ocean.[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Piantadosi-2003-133)[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-142)
triples.statement: The human population is not uniformly distributed across the Earth's surface, with varying population densities and large uninhabited areas like Antarctica and the oceans.

triples.sentence: Most humans (61%) live in Asia; the remainder live in the Americas (14%), Africa (14%), Europe (11%), and Oceania (0.5%).[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-143)
triples.statement: The majority of humans (61%) live in Asia, followed by the Americas (14%), Africa (14%), Europe (11%), and Oceania (0.5%).

triples.sentence: Humans and their domesticated animals represent 96% of all mammalian biomass on earth, whereas all wild mammals represent only 4%.[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Bar-On-144)
triples.statement: Humans and their domesticated animals account for 96% of all mammalian biomass on Earth, with wild mammals making up the remaining 4%.

triples.sentence: Around 50–60 million people lived in the combined eastern and western [Roman Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") in the 4th century AD.[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-147)
triples.statement: In the 4th century AD, the population of the combined eastern and western Roman Empire was approximately 50–60 million people.

triples.sentence: [Bubonic plagues](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bubonic_plague "Bubonic plague"), first recorded in the 6th century AD, reduced the population by 50%, with the [Black Death](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Death "Black Death") killing 75–200 million people in [Eurasia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurasia "Eurasia") and [North Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Africa "North Africa") alone.[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-148)
triples.statement: Bubonic plagues, first recorded in the 6th century AD, reduced the population by 50%, and the Black Death killed 75–200 million people in Eurasia and North Africa.

triples.sentence: It has since then increased exponentially, reaching two billion in 1930 and three billion in 1960, four in 1975, five in 1987 and six billion in 1999.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-149)
triples.statement: The human population increased exponentially after 1800, reaching six billion in 1999.

triples.sentence: It passed seven billion in 2011[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-150) and passed eight billion in November 2022.[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-151)
triples.statement: The world population surpassed seven billion in 2011 and eight billion in November 2022.

triples.sentence: It took over two million years of [human prehistory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prehistory "Prehistory") and [history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_history "Human history") for the human population to reach one [billion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billion "Billion") and only 207 years more to grow to 7 billion.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-152)
triples.statement: It took over two million years for the human population to reach one billion, but only another 207 years to grow to 7 billion.

triples.sentence: The combined [biomass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biomass_(ecology) "Biomass (ecology)") of the carbon of all the humans on Earth in 2018 was estimated at 60 million tons, about 10 times larger than that of all non-domesticated mammals.[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Bar-On-144)
triples.statement: In 2018, the combined carbon biomass of all humans was estimated at 60 million tons, approximately 10 times greater than that of all wild mammals.

triples.sentence: In 2018, 4.2 billion humans (55%) lived in urban areas, up from 751 million in 1950.[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-United_Nations_Department_of_Economic_and_Social_Affairs_(DESA)-2018-153)
triples.statement: In 2018, 4.2 billion people (55% of the population) lived in urban areas, an increase from 751 million in 1950.

triples.sentence: The most urbanized regions are Northern America (82%), Latin America (81%), Europe (74%) and Oceania (68%), with Africa and Asia having nearly 90% of the world's 3.4 billion rural population.[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-United_Nations_Department_of_Economic_and_Social_Affairs_(DESA)-2018-153)
triples.statement: The most urbanized regions are Northern America (82%), Latin America (81%), Europe (74%), and Oceania (68%), while Africa and Asia contain almost 90% of the world's 3.4 billion rural inhabitants.

triples.sentence: Problems for humans living in cities include various forms of pollution and [crime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crime "Crime"),[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-154) especially in inner city and suburban [slums](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slum "Slum").
triples.statement: Problems for urban dwellers include pollution and crime, particularly in inner-city and suburban slums.

section_body:
Main article: [Human body](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_body "Human body")

[![Image 18](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Anterior_view_of_human_female_and_male%2C_with_labels_2.png/500px-Anterior_view_of_human_female_and_male%2C_with_labels_2.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Anterior_view_of_human_female_and_male,_with_labels_2.png)

Basic anatomical features of female and male humans. These models have had [body hair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_hair "Body hair") and male [facial hair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_hair "Facial hair") removed and head hair trimmed.

Most aspects of human physiology are closely [homologous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homology_(biology) "Homology (biology)") to corresponding aspects of animal physiology. The [dental formula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dental_formula "Dental formula") of humans is: 2.1.2.3 2.1.2.3, like other [catarrhines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catarrhini "Catarrhini"). Humans have proportionately shorter [palates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palate "Palate") and much smaller [teeth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_tooth "Human tooth") than other primates. They are the only primates to have short, relatively flush [canine teeth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canine_teeth "Canine teeth"). Humans have characteristically crowded teeth, with gaps from lost teeth usually closing up quickly in young individuals. Humans are gradually losing their [third molars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wisdom_teeth "Wisdom teeth"), with some individuals having them congenitally absent.[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Revolution-155)

Humans share with chimpanzees a [vestigial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vestigiality "Vestigiality") tail,[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-156)[appendix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appendix_(anatomy) "Appendix (anatomy)"), flexible shoulder joints, grasping fingers and [opposable thumbs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opposable_thumb "Opposable thumb").[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-157) Humans also have a more barrel-shaped chest in contrast to the funnel shape of other apes, an adaptation for bipedal respiration.[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-158) Apart from bipedalism and brain size, humans differ from chimpanzees mostly in [smelling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smelling "Smelling"), [hearing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearing "Hearing") and [digesting proteins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digestion#Protein_digestion "Digestion").[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-O'Neil-159) While humans have a density of [hair follicles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hair_follicle "Hair follicle") comparable to other apes, it is predominantly [vellus hair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vellus_hair "Vellus hair"), most of which is so short and wispy as to be practically invisible.[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-160)[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-161) Humans have about 2 million [sweat glands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweat_gland "Sweat gland") spread over their entire bodies, many more than chimpanzees, whose sweat glands are scarce and are mainly located on the palm of the hand and on the soles of the feet.[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-162)

It is estimated that the worldwide average [height for an adult human](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_height "Human height") male is about 171 cm (5 ft 7 in), while the worldwide average height for adult human females is about 159 cm (5 ft 3 in).[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-163) Shrinkage of stature may begin in middle age in some individuals but tends to be typical in the extremely [aged](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_age "Old age").[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-164) Throughout history, human populations have universally become taller, probably as a consequence of better nutrition, healthcare, and living conditions.[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-165) The average [mass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_weight "Body weight") of an adult human is 59 kg (130 lb) for females and 77 kg (170 lb) for males.[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-166)[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-167) Like many other conditions, body weight and body type are influenced by both [genetic susceptibility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_predisposition "Genetic predisposition") and environment and varies greatly among individuals.[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-168)[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-169)

Humans have a far faster and more accurate [throw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Throw "Throw") than other animals.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-170) Humans are also among the best long-distance runners in the animal kingdom, but slower over short distances.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-171)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-O'Neil-159) Humans' thinner body hair and more productive sweat glands help avoid [heat exhaustion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_exhaustion "Heat exhaustion") while running for long distances.[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-172) Compared to other apes, the human [heart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heart "Heart") produces greater [stroke volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stroke_volume "Stroke volume") and [cardiac output](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardiac_output "Cardiac output") and the [aorta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aorta "Aorta") is proportionately larger.[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-173)[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-174)

triples.sentence: Humans are gradually losing their [third molars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wisdom_teeth "Wisdom teeth"), with some individuals having them congenitally absent.[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Revolution-155)
triples.statement: Humans are gradually losing their third molars, with some individuals having them congenitally absent.

triples.sentence: Apart from bipedalism and brain size, humans differ from chimpanzees mostly in [smelling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smelling "Smelling"), [hearing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearing "Hearing") and [digesting proteins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digestion#Protein_digestion "Digestion").[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-O'Neil-159)
triples.statement: Besides bipedalism and brain size, humans differ from chimpanzees primarily in smelling, hearing, and protein digestion.

triples.sentence: While humans have a density of [hair follicles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hair_follicle "Hair follicle") comparable to other apes, it is predominantly [vellus hair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vellus_hair "Vellus hair"), most of which is so short and wispy as to be practically invisible.[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-160)[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-161)
triples.statement: Although humans have a hair follicle density comparable to other apes, their hair is predominantly vellus hair, which is so short and fine as to be nearly invisible.

triples.sentence: Humans have about 2 million [sweat glands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweat_gland "Sweat gland") spread over their entire bodies, many more than chimpanzees, whose sweat glands are scarce and are mainly located on the palm of the hand and on the soles of the feet.[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-162)
triples.statement: Humans have about 2 million sweat glands spread over their bodies, far more than chimpanzees, whose glands are scarce and located mainly on their palms and soles.

triples.sentence: It is estimated that the worldwide average [height for an adult human](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_height "Human height") male is about 171 cm (5 ft 7 in), while the worldwide average height for adult human females is about 159 cm (5 ft 3 in).[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-163)
triples.statement: The estimated worldwide average height for an adult human male is about 171 cm (5 ft 7 in), while for an adult female it is about 159 cm (5 ft 3 in).

triples.sentence: The average [mass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_weight "Body weight") of an adult human is 59 kg (130 lb) for females and 77 kg (170 lb) for males.[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-166)[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-167)
triples.statement: The average mass of an adult human is 59 kg (130 lb) for females and 77 kg (170 lb) for males.

triples.sentence: Like many other conditions, body weight and body type are influenced by both [genetic susceptibility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_predisposition "Genetic predisposition") and environment and varies greatly among individuals.[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-168)[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-169)
triples.statement: Body weight and body type are influenced by both genetic susceptibility and environment, and they vary greatly among individuals.

triples.sentence: Humans are also among the best long-distance runners in the animal kingdom, but slower over short distances.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-171)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-O'Neil-159)
triples.statement: Humans are among the best long-distance runners in the animal kingdom, but are slower over short distances.

triples.sentence: Humans' thinner body hair and more productive sweat glands help avoid [heat exhaustion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_exhaustion "Heat exhaustion") while running for long distances.[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-172)
triples.statement: Thinner body hair and more productive sweat glands help humans avoid heat exhaustion while running for long distances.

triples.sentence: Compared to other apes, the human [heart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heart "Heart") produces greater [stroke volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stroke_volume "Stroke volume") and [cardiac output](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardiac_output "Cardiac output") and the [aorta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aorta "Aorta") is proportionately larger.[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-173)[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-174)
triples.statement: Compared to other apes, the human heart produces a greater stroke volume and cardiac output, and the aorta is proportionately larger.

section_body:
Main article: [Human genetics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genetics "Human genetics")

[![Image 19](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Karyotype.png/250px-Karyotype.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Karyotype.png)

A graphical representation of the standard human [karyotype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karyotype "Karyotype"), including both the female (XX) and male (XY) sex chromosomes.

Humans are, like most animals, [plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant "Plant"), and [fungi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fungus "Fungus"), a [eukaryotic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eukaryote "Eukaryote"), and like most animals a [diploid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ploidy "Ploidy") species. Each [somatic cell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Somatic_cell "Somatic cell") has two sets of 23 [chromosomes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chromosome "Chromosome"), each set received from one parent; [gametes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamete "Gamete") have only one set of chromosomes, which is a mixture of the two parental sets. Among the 23 pairs of chromosomes, there are 22 pairs of [autosomes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autosome "Autosome") and one pair of [sex chromosomes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex-determination_system "Sex-determination system"). Like other mammals, humans have an [XY sex-determination system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XY_sex-determination_system "XY sex-determination system"), so that females have the sex chromosomes XX and males have XY.[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-175)[Genes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene "Gene") and [environment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environment_(biophysical) "Environment (biophysical)") influence human biological variation in visible characteristics, physiology, disease susceptibility and mental abilities. The exact influence of [genes and environment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environment_(biophysical) "Environment (biophysical)") on certain traits is not well understood.[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-176)[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-177)

While no humans– not even [monozygotic twins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monozygotic_twins "Monozygotic twins")– are genetically identical,[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-178) two humans on average will have a genetic similarity of 99.5%-99.9%.[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-179)[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-180) This makes them more [homogeneous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genetic_variation "Human genetic variation") than other great apes, including chimpanzees.[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-REGWG2005-181)[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-182) This small variation in human DNA compared to many other species suggests a [population bottleneck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_bottleneck "Population bottleneck") during the [Late Pleistocene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Pleistocene "Late Pleistocene") (around 100,000 years ago), in which the human population was reduced to a small number of breeding pairs.[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-183)[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-184) The forces of [natural selection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_selection "Natural selection") have continued to operate on human populations, with evidence that certain regions of the [genome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genome "Genome") display [directional selection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directional_selection "Directional selection") in the past 15,000 years.[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-185)

The [human genome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genome "Human genome") was first sequenced in 2001[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-186) and by 2020 hundreds of thousands of genomes had been sequenced.[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-187) In 2012 the [International HapMap Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_HapMap_Project "International HapMap Project") had compared the genomes of 1,184 individuals from 11 populations and identified 1.6 million [single nucleotide polymorphisms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_nucleotide_polymorphisms "Single nucleotide polymorphisms").[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-188) African populations harbor the highest number of private genetic variants. While many of the common variants found in populations outside of Africa are also found on the African continent, there are still large numbers that are private to these regions, especially [Oceania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oceania "Oceania") and [the Americas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Americas "The Americas").[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Bergstrom2020-189) By 2010 estimates, humans have approximately 22,000 genes.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-190) By comparing [mitochondrial DNA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MtDNA "MtDNA"), which is inherited only from the mother, geneticists have concluded that the last female common ancestor whose [genetic marker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_marker "Genetic marker") is found in all modern humans, the so-called [mitochondrial Eve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitochondrial_Eve "Mitochondrial Eve"), must have lived around 90,000 to 200,000 years ago.[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-191)[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-192)[[191]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-193)[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-194)

triples.sentence: While no humans– not even [monozygotic twins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monozygotic_twins "Monozygotic twins")– are genetically identical,[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-178) two humans on average will have a genetic similarity of 99.5%-99.9%.[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-179)[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-180)
triples.statement: Although no two humans are genetically identical, any two humans share an average genetic similarity of 99.5% to 99.9%.

triples.sentence: This makes them more [homogeneous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genetic_variation "Human genetic variation") than other great apes, including chimpanzees.[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-REGWG2005-181)[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-182)
triples.statement: This high genetic similarity makes humans more homogeneous than other great apes like chimpanzees.

triples.sentence: This small variation in human DNA compared to many other species suggests a [population bottleneck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_bottleneck "Population bottleneck") during the [Late Pleistocene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Pleistocene "Late Pleistocene") (around 100,000 years ago), in which the human population was reduced to a small number of breeding pairs.[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-183)[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-184)
triples.statement: The low genetic variation in humans compared to other species suggests a population bottleneck occurred around 100,000 years ago during the Late Pleistocene, reducing the population to a few breeding pairs.

triples.sentence: The forces of [natural selection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_selection "Natural selection") have continued to operate on human populations, with evidence that certain regions of the [genome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genome "Genome") display [directional selection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directional_selection "Directional selection") in the past 15,000 years.[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-185)
triples.statement: Natural selection continues to affect human populations, with evidence of directional selection in parts of the genome over the last 15,000 years.

triples.sentence: In 2012 the [International HapMap Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_HapMap_Project "International HapMap Project") had compared the genomes of 1,184 individuals from 11 populations and identified 1.6 million [single nucleotide polymorphisms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_nucleotide_polymorphisms "Single nucleotide polymorphisms").[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-188)
triples.statement: In 2012, the International HapMap Project identified 1.6 million single nucleotide polymorphisms by comparing the genomes of 1,184 individuals from 11 different populations.

triples.sentence: While many of the common variants found in populations outside of Africa are also found on the African continent, there are still large numbers that are private to these regions, especially [Oceania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oceania "Oceania") and [the Americas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Americas "The Americas").[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Bergstrom2020-189)
triples.statement: Although many common genetic variants in non-African populations are also present in Africa, regions like Oceania and the Americas have a large number of private variants.

triples.sentence: By 2010 estimates, humans have approximately 22,000 genes.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-190)
triples.statement: As of 2010 estimates, humans possess around 22,000 genes.

triples.sentence: By comparing [mitochondrial DNA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MtDNA "MtDNA"), which is inherited only from the mother, geneticists have concluded that the last female common ancestor whose [genetic marker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_marker "Genetic marker") is found in all modern humans, the so-called [mitochondrial Eve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitochondrial_Eve "Mitochondrial Eve"), must have lived around 90,000 to 200,000 years ago.[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-191)[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-192)[[191]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-193)[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-194)
triples.statement: Analysis of mitochondrial DNA, inherited from the mother, indicates that the most recent common female ancestor of all living humans (Mitochondrial Eve) lived between 90,000 and 200,000 years ago.

section_body:
See also: [Childbirth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Childbirth "Childbirth") and [Life expectancy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_expectancy "Life expectancy")

[![Image 20](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Tubal_Pregnancy_with_embryo.jpg/250px-Tubal_Pregnancy_with_embryo.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tubal_Pregnancy_with_embryo.jpg)

A 10 mm [human embryo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_embryo "Human embryo") at 5 weeks

Most [human reproduction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_reproduction "Human reproduction") takes place by [internal fertilization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_fertilization "Internal fertilization") via [sexual intercourse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_sexual_intercourse "Human sexual intercourse"), but can also occur through [assisted reproductive technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assisted_reproductive_technology "Assisted reproductive technology") procedures.[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-195) The average [gestation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gestation "Gestation") period is 38 weeks, but a normal pregnancy can vary by up to 37 days.[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-196) Embryonic development in the human covers the first eight weeks of development; at the beginning of the ninth week the embryo is termed a [fetus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fetus "Fetus").[[195]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-197) Humans are able to [induce early labor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_induction "Labor induction") or perform a [caesarean section](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caesarean_section "Caesarean section") if the child needs to be born earlier for medical reasons.[[196]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-198) In developed countries, [infants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infant "Infant") are typically 3–4 kg (7–9 lb) in weight and 47–53 cm (19–21 in) in height at birth.[[197]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-199)[[198]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-200) However, [low birth weight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low_birth_weight "Low birth weight") is common in developing countries, and contributes to the high levels of [infant mortality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infant_mortality "Infant mortality") in these regions.[[199]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-201)

Compared with other species, human childbirth is dangerous, with a much higher risk of complications and death.[[200]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-202) The size of the fetus's head is more closely matched to the [pelvis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pelvis "Pelvis") than in other primates.[[201]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Pavlicev-203) The reason for this is not completely understood,[[n 3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-205) but it contributes to a painful labor that can last 24 hours or more.[[203]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-206) The chances of a successful labor increased significantly during the 20th century in wealthier countries with the advent of new medical technologies. In contrast, pregnancy and [natural childbirth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_childbirth "Natural childbirth") remain hazardous ordeals in developing regions of the world, with [maternal death rates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maternal_death_rates "Maternal death rates") approximately 100 times greater than in developed countries.[[204]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-207)

Both the mother and the father provide care for human offspring, in contrast to other primates, where parental care is mostly done by the mother.[[205]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-208)[Helpless at birth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altricial "Altricial"), humans continue to grow for some years, typically reaching [sexual maturity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_maturity "Sexual maturity") at 15 to 17 years of age.[[206]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-209)[[207]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-210)[[208]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-211) The human life span has been split into various stages ranging from three to twelve. Common stages include [infancy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infant "Infant"), [childhood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Childhood "Childhood"), [adolescence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolescence "Adolescence"), [adulthood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adult "Adult") and [old age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_age "Old age").[[209]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-212) The lengths of these stages have varied across cultures and time periods but is typified by an unusually rapid growth spurt during adolescence.[[210]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-213) Human females undergo [menopause](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menopause "Menopause") and become [infertile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infertility "Infertility") at around the age of 50.[[211]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-214) It has been proposed that menopause increases a woman's overall reproductive success by allowing her to invest more time and resources in her existing offspring, and in turn their children (the [grandmother hypothesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grandmother_hypothesis "Grandmother hypothesis")), rather than by continuing to bear children into old age.[[212]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-215)[[213]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-216)

The life span of an individual depends on two major factors, genetics and lifestyle choices.[[214]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-217) For various reasons, including biological/genetic causes, women live on average about four years longer than men.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-218) As of 2018[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Human&action=edit), the global average [life expectancy at birth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_expectancy_at_birth "Life expectancy at birth") of a girl is estimated to be 74.9 years compared to 70.4 for a boy.[[216]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-219)[[217]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-220) There are significant geographical variations in human life expectancy, mostly correlated with economic development– for example, life expectancy at birth in [Hong Kong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong") is 87.6 years for girls and 81.8 for boys, while in the [Central African Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_African_Republic "Central African Republic"), it is 55.0 years for girls and 50.6 for boys.[[218]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-221)[[219]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-222) The developed world is generally aging, with the median age around 40 years. In the [developing world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_world "Third world"), the median age is between 15 and 20 years. While one in five Europeans is 60 years of age or older, only one in twenty Africans is 60 years of age or older.[[220]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-223) In 2012, the United Nations estimated that there were 316,600 living [centenarians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centenarians "Centenarians") (humans of age 100 or older) worldwide.[[221]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-224)

Human life stages [![Image 21](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Baby_with_Aerobie_flying_ring.jpg/120px-Baby_with_Aerobie_flying_ring.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Baby_with_Aerobie_flying_ring.jpg)[![Image 22](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BF%D1%87%D0%B8%D0%BA_%28%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%87%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BE%29.jpg/120px-%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BF%D1%87%D0%B8%D0%BA_%28%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%87%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BE%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BF%D1%87%D0%B8%D0%BA_(%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%87%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BE).jpg)[![Image 23](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Boy_in_Dar_es_Salaam_%2814453809622%29.jpg/120px-Boy_in_Dar_es_Salaam_%2814453809622%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Boy_in_Dar_es_Salaam_(14453809622).jpg)[![Image 24](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Pataxo001.jpg/120px-Pataxo001.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pataxo001.jpg)[![Image 25](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/An_old_age.JPG/120px-An_old_age.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:An_old_age.JPG)
[![Image 26](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Baby_playing_with_yellow_paint._Work_by_Dutch_artist_Peter_Klashorst_entitled_%22Experimental%22.jpg/120px-Baby_playing_with_yellow_paint._Work_by_Dutch_artist_Peter_Klashorst_entitled_%22Experimental%22.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Baby_playing_with_yellow_paint._Work_by_Dutch_artist_Peter_Klashorst_entitled_%22Experimental%22.jpg)[![Image 27](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Ethnie_dong_6511a.jpg/120px-Ethnie_dong_6511a.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ethnie_dong_6511a.jpg)[![Image 28](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Portrait_of_a_Persian_lady_in_Iran%2C_10-08-2006_%28cropped%29.jpg/120px-Portrait_of_a_Persian_lady_in_Iran%2C_10-08-2006_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Portrait_of_a_Persian_lady_in_Iran,_10-08-2006_(cropped).jpg)[![Image 29](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Punjabi_woman_smile.jpg/120px-Punjabi_woman_smile.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Punjabi_woman_smile.jpg)[![Image 30](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/HappyPensioneer.jpg/120px-HappyPensioneer.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:HappyPensioneer.jpg)
[Infant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infant "Infant") boy and girl Boy and girl before [puberty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puberty "Puberty") ([children](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Child "Child"))[Adolescent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolescent "Adolescent") male and female[Adult](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adult "Adult") man and woman[Elderly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elderly "Elderly") man and woman

triples.sentence: The average [gestation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gestation "Gestation") period is 38 weeks, but a normal pregnancy can vary by up to 37 days.[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-196)
triples.statement: The average gestation period is 38 weeks, though a normal pregnancy's length can vary by up to 37 days.

triples.sentence: Embryonic development in the human covers the first eight weeks of development; at the beginning of the ninth week the embryo is termed a [fetus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fetus "Fetus").[[195]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-197)
triples.statement: Human embryonic development spans the first eight weeks; from the ninth week onward, the embryo is called a fetus.

triples.sentence: Humans are able to [induce early labor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_induction "Labor induction") or perform a [caesarean section](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caesarean_section "Caesarean section") if the child needs to be born earlier for medical reasons.[[196]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-198)
triples.statement: Humans can induce early labor or perform a caesarean section if a child needs to be born earlier for medical reasons.

triples.sentence: In developed countries, [infants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infant "Infant") are typically 3–4 kg (7–9 lb) in weight and 47–53 cm (19–21 in) in height at birth.[[197]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-199)[[198]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-200)
triples.statement: In developed countries, infants typically weigh 3–4 kg (7–9 lb) and are 47–53 cm (19–21 in) in height at birth.

triples.sentence: However, [low birth weight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low_birth_weight "Low birth weight") is common in developing countries, and contributes to the high levels of [infant mortality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infant_mortality "Infant mortality") in these regions.[[199]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-201)
triples.statement: Low birth weight is common in developing countries and contributes to high levels of infant mortality in those regions.

triples.sentence: The size of the fetus's head is more closely matched to the [pelvis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pelvis "Pelvis") than in other primates.[[201]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Pavlicev-203)
triples.statement: The size of a human fetus's head is more closely matched to the pelvis than in other primates.

triples.sentence: The reason for this is not completely understood,[[n 3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-205) but it contributes to a painful labor that can last 24 hours or more.[[203]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-206)
triples.statement: Although the reason is not fully understood, this contributes to a painful labor that can last 24 hours or more.

triples.sentence: Both the mother and the father provide care for human offspring, in contrast to other primates, where parental care is mostly done by the mother.[[205]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-208)
triples.statement: Unlike other primates where mothers are the primary caregivers, both human mothers and fathers provide care for their offspring.

triples.sentence: The lengths of these stages have varied across cultures and time periods but is typified by an unusually rapid growth spurt during adolescence.[[210]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-213)
triples.statement: The duration of these life stages has varied across cultures and time periods but is characterized by a rapid growth spurt during adolescence.

triples.sentence: Human females undergo [menopause](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menopause "Menopause") and become [infertile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infertility "Infertility") at around the age of 50.[[211]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-214)
triples.statement: Human females experience menopause and become infertile around the age of 50.

triples.sentence: The life span of an individual depends on two major factors, genetics and lifestyle choices.[[214]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-217)
triples.statement: An individual's life span is determined by two main factors: genetics and lifestyle choices.

triples.sentence: For various reasons, including biological/genetic causes, women live on average about four years longer than men.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-218)
triples.statement: For various reasons, including biological and genetic causes, women live on average about four years longer than men.

triples.sentence: As of 2018[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Human&action=edit), the global average [life expectancy at birth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_expectancy_at_birth "Life expectancy at birth") of a girl is estimated to be 74.9 years compared to 70.4 for a boy.[[216]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-219)[[217]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-220)
triples.statement: As of 2018, the global average life expectancy at birth was estimated to be 74.9 years for a girl and 70.4 years for a boy.

triples.sentence: There are significant geographical variations in human life expectancy, mostly correlated with economic development– for example, life expectancy at birth in [Hong Kong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong") is 87.6 years for girls and 81.8 for boys, while in the [Central African Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_African_Republic "Central African Republic"), it is 55.0 years for girls and 50.6 for boys.[[218]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-221)[[219]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-222)
triples.statement: Human life expectancy varies significantly by geography and is largely correlated with economic development; for instance, life expectancy at birth in Hong Kong is 87.6 years for girls and 81.8 for boys, whereas in the Central African Republic, it is 55.0 for girls and 50.6 for boys.

triples.sentence: While one in five Europeans is 60 years of age or older, only one in twenty Africans is 60 years of age or older.[[220]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-223)
triples.statement: While one in five Europeans is 60 years of age or older, only one in twenty Africans is 60 or older.

triples.sentence: In 2012, the United Nations estimated that there were 316,600 living [centenarians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centenarians "Centenarians") (humans of age 100 or older) worldwide.[[221]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-224)
triples.statement: In 2012, the United Nations estimated that there were 316,600 living centenarians (people aged 100 or older) worldwide.

section_body:
Main article: [Human nutrition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_nutrition "Human nutrition")

[![Image 31](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Preparing_The_Feast.jpg/250px-Preparing_The_Feast.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Preparing_The_Feast.jpg)

Humans living in [Bali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bali "Bali"), [Indonesia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia"), preparing a meal

Humans are [omnivorous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omnivorous "Omnivorous"),[[222]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-225) capable of consuming a wide variety of plant and animal material.[[223]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-226)[[224]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-227) Human groups have adopted a range of diets from purely [vegan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegan "Vegan") to primarily [carnivorous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous"). In some cases, dietary restrictions in humans can lead to [deficiency diseases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deficiency_diseases "Deficiency diseases"); however, stable human groups have adapted to many dietary patterns through both genetic specialization and cultural conventions to use nutritionally balanced food sources.[[225]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-228) The human diet is prominently reflected in human culture and has led to the development of [food science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_science "Food science").[[226]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Crittenden-2017-229)

Until the development of agriculture, _Homo sapiens_ employed a hunter-gatherer method as their sole means of food collection.[[226]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Crittenden-2017-229) This involved combining stationary food sources (such as fruits, grains, tubers, and mushrooms, insect larvae and aquatic mollusks) with [wild game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_(food) "Game (food)"), which must be hunted and captured in order to be consumed.[[227]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-230) It has been proposed that humans have used fire to prepare and [cook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooking "Cooking") food since the time of _[Homo erectus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homo\_erectus "Homo erectus")_.[[228]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-231) Human [domestication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestication "Domestication") of wild plants began about 11,700 years ago, leading to the [development of agriculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_agriculture "History of agriculture"),[[229]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-232) a gradual process called the [Neolithic Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neolithic_Revolution "Neolithic Revolution").[[230]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-233) These dietary changes may also have altered human biology; the spread of [dairy farming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dairy_farming "Dairy farming") provided a new and rich source of food, leading to the evolution of the ability to digest [lactose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lactose "Lactose") in some adults.[[231]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-234)[[232]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-235) The types of food consumed, and how they are prepared, have varied widely by time, location, and culture.[[233]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-236)[[234]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-237)

In general, humans can survive for up to eight weeks without food, depending on stored body fat.[[235]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-238) Survival without water is usually limited to three or four days, with a maximum of one week.[[236]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-239) In 2020, it was estimated 9 million humans die every year from causes directly or indirectly related to [starvation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starvation "Starvation").[[237]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-240)[[238]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-241) Childhood malnutrition is also common and contributes to the [global burden of disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disease_burden "Disease burden").[[239]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-242) However, global food distribution is not even, and [obesity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obesity "Obesity") among some human populations has increased rapidly, leading to health complications and increased mortality in some [developed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Developed_country "Developed country") and a few [developing countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Developing_countries "Developing countries"). Worldwide, over one billion people are obese,[[240]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Haslam-243) while in the United States 35% of people are obese, leading to this being described as an "[obesity epidemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemiology_of_obesity "Epidemiology of obesity")."[[241]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-244) Obesity is caused by consuming more [calories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calorie "Calorie") than are expended, so excessive weight gain is usually caused by an energy-dense diet.[[240]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Haslam-243)

Food consumption is the first step of the [digestive process](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_digestive_system "Human digestive system"), in which humans ultimately expel [feces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_feces "Human feces") ranging in frequency from multiple times per day to multiple times per week.[[242]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-245)

triples.sentence: This involved combining stationary food sources (such as fruits, grains, tubers, and mushrooms, insect larvae and aquatic mollusks) with [wild game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_(food) "Game (food)"), which must be hunted and captured in order to be consumed.[[227]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-230)
triples.statement: The hunter-gatherer method involved combining stationary food sources like fruits and tubers with hunted wild game.

triples.sentence: It has been proposed that humans have used fire to prepare and [cook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooking "Cooking") food since the time of _[Homo erectus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homo_erectus "Homo erectus")_.[[228]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-231)
triples.statement: It is proposed that humans have used fire for cooking since the time of Homo erectus.

triples.sentence: Human [domestication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestication "Domestication") of wild plants began about 11,700 years ago, leading to the [development of agriculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_agriculture "History of agriculture"),[[229]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-232) a gradual process called the [Neolithic Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neolithic_Revolution "Neolithic Revolution").[[230]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-233)
triples.statement: The domestication of wild plants by humans, which led to agriculture, began about 11,700 years ago in a process known as the Neolithic Revolution.

triples.sentence: These dietary changes may also have altered human biology; the spread of [dairy farming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dairy_farming "Dairy farming") provided a new and rich source of food, leading to the evolution of the ability to digest [lactose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lactose "Lactose") in some adults.[[231]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-234)[[232]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-235)
triples.statement: Dietary changes, such as the spread of dairy farming, may have altered human biology, leading to the evolution of lactose digestion in some adults.

triples.sentence: The types of food consumed, and how they are prepared, have varied widely by time, location, and culture.[[233]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-236)[[234]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-237)
triples.statement: The types of food humans eat and their preparation methods have varied greatly across time, location, and culture.

triples.sentence: In general, humans can survive for up to eight weeks without food, depending on stored body fat.[[235]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-238)
triples.statement: Depending on stored body fat, humans can generally survive for up to eight weeks without food.

triples.sentence: Survival without water is usually limited to three or four days, with a maximum of one week.[[236]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-239)
triples.statement: Humans can typically survive without water for three to four days, and at most for one week.

triples.sentence: In 2020, it was estimated 9 million humans die every year from causes directly or indirectly related to [starvation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starvation "Starvation").[[237]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-240)[[238]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-241)
triples.statement: In 2020, an estimated 9 million people died annually from causes related to starvation.

triples.sentence: Food consumption is the first step of the [digestive process](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_digestive_system "Human digestive system"), in which humans ultimately expel [feces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_feces "Human feces") ranging in frequency from multiple times per day to multiple times per week.[[242]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-245)
triples.statement: Food consumption is the initial step in the digestive process, which concludes with the expulsion of feces at a frequency ranging from several times a day to several times a week.

section_body:
Main article: [Human genetic variation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genetic_variation "Human genetic variation")

[![Image 32](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Seti1a.jpg/250px-Seti1a.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seti1a.jpg)

A [Libyan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berbers "Berbers"), a [Nubian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nubians "Nubians"), a [Syrian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syrian_people "Syrian people"), and an [Egyptian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptians "Egyptians"), drawing by an unknown artist after a mural of the tomb of [Seti I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seti_I "Seti I")

There is biological variation in the human species– with traits such as [blood type](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blood_type "Blood type"), [genetic diseases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_diseases "Genetic diseases"), [cranial features](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_skull "Human skull"), [facial features](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_face "Human face"), [organ systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organ_systems "Organ systems"), [eye color](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eye_color "Eye color"), [hair color](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hair_color "Hair color") and [texture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hair_texture "Hair texture"), [height](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_height "Human height") and [build](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_shape "Body shape"), and [skin color](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_skin_color "Human skin color") varying across the globe. The typical height of an adult human is between 1.4 and 1.9 m (4 ft 7 in and 6 ft 3 in), although this varies significantly depending on sex, [ethnic origin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_origin "Ethnic origin"), and family bloodlines.[[243]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-246)[[244]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-247) Body size is partly determined by genes and is also significantly influenced by environmental factors such as [diet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diet_(nutrition) "Diet (nutrition)"), exercise, and [sleep patterns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleep_pattern "Sleep pattern").[[245]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-248)

[![Image 33](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Hair_colors.jpg/250px-Hair_colors.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hair_colors.jpg)

A variety of human hair colors; from top left, clockwise: [black](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_hair "Black hair"), [brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brown_hair "Brown hair"), [blonde](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blond "Blond"), [white](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_hair "White hair"), [red](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_hair "Red hair").

There is evidence that populations have adapted genetically to various external factors. The genes that allow adult humans to [digest lactose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lactose_tolerance "Lactose tolerance") are present in high frequencies in populations that have long histories of cattle domestication and are more dependent on [cow milk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cow_milk "Cow milk").[[246]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-249)[Sickle cell anemia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sickle_cell_anemia "Sickle cell anemia"), which may provide increased resistance to [malaria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaria "Malaria"), is frequent in populations where [malaria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaria "Malaria") is endemic.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-250)[[248]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-251) Populations that have for a very long time inhabited specific climates tend to have developed specific [phenotypes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype "Phenotype") that are beneficial for those environments– [short stature and stocky build in cold regions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen%27s_rule "Allen's rule"), tall and lanky in hot regions, and with high lung capacities or other [adaptations at high altitudes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-altitude_adaptation_in_humans "High-altitude adaptation in humans").[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-252) Some populations have evolved highly unique adaptations to very specific environmental conditions, such as those advantageous to ocean-dwelling lifestyles and [freediving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freediving "Freediving") in the [Bajau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bajau "Bajau").[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-253)

Human hair ranges in color from [red](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_hair "Red hair") to [blond](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blond "Blond") to [brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brown_hair "Brown hair") to [black](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_hair "Black hair"), which is the most frequent.[[251]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-254) Hair color depends on the amount of [melanin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melanin "Melanin"), with concentrations fading with increased age, leading to [grey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey_hair "Grey hair") or even white hair. Skin color can range from [darkest brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_skin "Dark skin") to [lightest peach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light_skin "Light skin"), or even nearly white or colorless in cases of [albinism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albinism "Albinism").[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-roberts1-255) It tends to vary [clinally](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinal_variation "Clinal variation") and generally correlates with the level of [ultraviolet radiation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultraviolet "Ultraviolet") in a particular geographic area, with darker skin mostly around the equator.[[253]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-256) Skin darkening may have evolved as protection against ultraviolet solar radiation.[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-257) Light skin pigmentation protects against depletion of [vitamin D](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vitamin_D "Vitamin D"), which requires [sunlight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunlight "Sunlight") to make.[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-258) Human skin also has a capacity to darken (tan) in response to exposure to ultraviolet radiation.[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-259)[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-260)

There is relatively little variation between human geographical populations, and most of the variation that occurs is at the individual level.[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-roberts1-255)[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-261)[[259]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-262) Much of human variation is continuous, often with no clear points of demarcation.[[260]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-263)[[261]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-264)[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-265)[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-266) Genetic data shows that no matter how population groups are defined, two people from the same population group are almost as different from each other as two people from any two different population groups.[[264]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-267)[[265]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-268)[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-269) Dark-skinned populations that are found in Africa, Australia, and South Asia are not closely related to each other.[[267]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-270)[[268]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-271)

Genetic research has demonstrated that human populations native to the [African continent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_continent "African continent") are the most genetically diverse[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-272) and genetic diversity decreases with migratory distance from Africa, possibly the result of [bottlenecks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_bottleneck "Evolutionary bottleneck") during human migration.[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-273)[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-274) These non-African populations acquired new genetic inputs from local [admixture with archaic populations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interbreeding_between_archaic_and_modern_humans "Interbreeding between archaic and modern humans") and have much greater variation from Neanderthals and [Denisovans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denisovans "Denisovans") than is found in Africa,[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Bergstrom2020-189) though Neanderthal admixture into African populations may be underestimated.[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-275) Furthermore, recent studies have found that populations in [sub-Saharan Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa "Sub-Saharan Africa"), and particularly [West Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Africa "West Africa"), have ancestral genetic variation which predates modern humans and has been lost in most non-African populations. Some of this ancestry is thought to originate from admixture with an [unknown archaic hominin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interbreeding_between_archaic_and_modern_humans#Archaic_African_hominins "Interbreeding between archaic and modern humans") that diverged before the split of Neanderthals and modern humans.[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-276)[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-277)

Humans are a [gonochoric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gonochorism "Gonochorism") species, meaning they are divided into male and female [sexes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex "Sex").[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-278)[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-279)[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-280) The greatest degree of genetic [variation exists between males and females](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_differences_in_humans "Sex differences in humans"). While the [nucleotide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nucleotide_diversity "Nucleotide diversity") genetic variation of individuals of the same sex across global populations is no greater than 0.1%–0.5%, the genetic difference between [males](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man "Man") and [females](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woman "Woman") is between 1% and 2%. Males on average are 15% heavier and 15 cm (6 in) taller than females.[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-281)[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-282) On average, men have about 40–50% more upper-body strength and 20–30% more lower-body strength than women at the same weight, due to higher amounts of muscle and larger muscle fibers.[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-283) Women generally have a higher [body fat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_fat "Body fat") percentage than men.[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-284) Women have [lighter skin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_skin_color#Sexual_dimorphism "Human skin color") than men of the same population; this has been explained by a higher need for vitamin D in females during pregnancy and [lactation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lactation "Lactation").[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-285) As there are chromosomal differences between females and males, some X and Y chromosome-related conditions and [disorders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disease "Disease") only affect either men or women.[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-286) After allowing for body weight and volume, the male voice is usually an [octave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Octave "Octave") deeper than the female voice.[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-287) Women have a [longer life span](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_differences_in_longevity "Sex differences in longevity") in almost every population around the world.[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-288) There are [intersex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intersex "Intersex") conditions in the human population, however these are rare.[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-289)[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-290)

triples.sentence: Body size is partly determined by genes and is also significantly influenced by environmental factors such as [diet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diet_(nutrition) "Diet (nutrition)"), exercise, and [sleep patterns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleep_pattern "Sleep pattern").[[245]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-248)
triples.statement: Body size is determined by both genes and environmental factors like diet, exercise, and sleep patterns.

triples.sentence: The genes that allow adult humans to [digest lactose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lactose_tolerance "Lactose tolerance") are present in high frequencies in populations that have long histories of cattle domestication and are more dependent on [cow milk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cow_milk "Cow milk").[[246]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-249)
triples.statement: Genes for lactose digestion in adults are more frequent in populations with long histories of cattle domestication and dependence on cow milk.

triples.sentence: Populations that have for a very long time inhabited specific climates tend to have developed specific [phenotypes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype "Phenotype") that are beneficial for those environments– [short stature and stocky build in cold regions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen%27s_rule "Allen's rule"), tall and lanky in hot regions, and with high lung capacities or other [adaptations at high altitudes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-altitude_adaptation_in_humans "High-altitude adaptation in humans").[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-252)
triples.statement: Populations in specific climates for long periods tend to develop beneficial phenotypes, such as short, stocky builds in cold regions, tall, lanky builds in hot regions, and high lung capacities at high altitudes.

triples.sentence: Some populations have evolved highly unique adaptations to very specific environmental conditions, such as those advantageous to ocean-dwelling lifestyles and [freediving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freediving "Freediving") in the [Bajau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bajau "Bajau").[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-253)
triples.statement: Some populations, like the Bajau, have evolved unique adaptations for specific conditions, such as an ocean-dwelling lifestyle and freediving.

triples.sentence: Skin darkening may have evolved as protection against ultraviolet solar radiation.[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-257)
triples.statement: Skin darkening may have evolved to protect against ultraviolet solar radiation.

triples.sentence: Light skin pigmentation protects against depletion of [vitamin D](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vitamin_D "Vitamin D"), which requires [sunlight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunlight "Sunlight") to make.[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-258)
triples.statement: Light skin pigmentation helps prevent vitamin D depletion, as sunlight is needed for its production.

triples.sentence: Genetic data shows that no matter how population groups are defined, two people from the same population group are almost as different from each other as two people from any two different population groups.[[264]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-267)[[265]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-268)[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-269)
triples.statement: Genetic data indicates that two individuals from the same population group are nearly as different from each other as two individuals from any two different population groups.

triples.sentence: Genetic research has demonstrated that human populations native to the [African continent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_continent "African continent") are the most genetically diverse[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-272) and genetic diversity decreases with migratory distance from Africa, possibly the result of [bottlenecks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_bottleneck "Evolutionary bottleneck") during human migration.[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-273)[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-274)
triples.statement: Genetic research shows that human populations native to Africa are the most genetically diverse, and this diversity decreases with migratory distance from Africa, possibly due to bottlenecks during migration.

triples.sentence: Some of this ancestry is thought to originate from admixture with an [unknown archaic hominin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interbreeding_between_archaic_and_modern_humans#Archaic_African_hominins "Interbreeding between archaic and modern humans") that diverged before the split of Neanderthals and modern humans.[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-276)[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-277)
triples.statement: Some of this ancestry is believed to come from admixture with an unknown archaic hominin that diverged before the split of Neanderthals and modern humans.

triples.sentence: Males on average are 15% heavier and 15 cm (6 in) taller than females.[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-281)[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-282)
triples.statement: On average, males are 15% heavier and 15 cm (6 in) taller than females.

triples.sentence: Women generally have a higher [body fat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_fat "Body fat") percentage than men.[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-284)
triples.statement: Women typically have a higher body fat percentage than men.

triples.sentence: Women have [lighter skin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_skin_color#Sexual_dimorphism "Human skin color") than men of the same population; this has been explained by a higher need for vitamin D in females during pregnancy and [lactation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lactation "Lactation").[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-285)
triples.statement: Within the same population, women have lighter skin than men, which is thought to be due to a greater need for vitamin D during pregnancy and lactation.

triples.sentence: As there are chromosomal differences between females and males, some X and Y chromosome-related conditions and [disorders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disease "Disease") only affect either men or women.[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-286)
triples.statement: Due to chromosomal differences, some X and Y chromosome-related conditions and disorders affect only men or only women.

triples.sentence: After allowing for body weight and volume, the male voice is usually an [octave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Octave "Octave") deeper than the female voice.[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-287)
triples.statement: After adjusting for body weight and volume, the male voice is typically an octave deeper than the female voice.

triples.sentence: Women have a [longer life span](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_differences_in_longevity "Sex differences in longevity") in almost every population around the world.[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-288)
triples.statement: In nearly every global population, women have a longer life span.

section_body:
Main article: [Psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology "Psychology")

[![Image 34](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/NIA_human_brain_drawing.jpg/250px-NIA_human_brain_drawing.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:NIA_human_brain_drawing.jpg)

Drawing of the [human brain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_brain "Human brain"), showing several important structures

The [human brain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_brain "Human brain"), the focal point of the [central nervous system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_nervous_system "Central nervous system") in humans, controls the [peripheral nervous system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peripheral_nervous_system "Peripheral nervous system"). In addition to controlling "lower", involuntary, or primarily [autonomic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system "Autonomic nervous system") activities such as [respiration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Respiration_(physiology) "Respiration (physiology)") and [digestion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digestion "Digestion"), it is also the locus of "higher" order functioning such as [thought](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thought "Thought"), [reasoning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reason "Reason"), and [abstraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstraction "Abstraction").[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-291) These [cognitive processes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mental_function "Mental function") constitute the [mind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mind "Mind"), and, along with their [behavioral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior "Behavior") consequences, are studied in the field of [psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology "Psychology").
