Main articles: [Tool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tool "Tool") and [Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technology "Technology")

[![Image 39: Train running on a track](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/JR-Maglev-MLX01-2.jpg/250px-JR-Maglev-MLX01-2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:JR-Maglev-MLX01-2.jpg)

The [SCMaglev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SCMaglev "SCMaglev"), the [fastest train](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_speed_record_for_rail_vehicles "Land speed record for rail vehicles") in the world clocking in at 603 km/h (375 mph) as of 2015[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-390)

Stone tools were used by proto-humans at least 2.5 million years ago.[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-391) The use and manufacture of tools has been put forward as the ability that defines humans more than anything else[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Choi-2009-392) and has historically been seen as an important evolutionary step.[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-393) The technology became much more sophisticated about 1.8 million years ago,[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Choi-2009-392) with the [controlled use of fire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_of_fire_by_early_humans "Control of fire by early humans") beginning around 1 million years ago.[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-394)[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-395) The wheel and wheeled vehicles appeared simultaneously in several regions some time in the fourth millennium BC.[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Bodn%C3%A1r-2018-65) The development of more complex tools and technologies allowed land to be [cultivated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arable_land "Arable land") and animals to be [domesticated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestication "Domestication"), thus proving essential in the development of [agriculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agriculture "Agriculture")– what is known as the [Neolithic Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neolithic_Revolution "Neolithic Revolution").[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-396)

[China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China "China") developed [paper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paper "Paper"), the [printing press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Printing_press "Printing press"), [gunpowder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunpowder "Gunpowder"), the [compass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compass "Compass") and [other important inventions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Chinese_inventions "List of Chinese inventions").[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-397) The continued improvements in [smelting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smelting "Smelting") allowed [forging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forging "Forging") of copper, bronze, iron and eventually [steel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steel "Steel"), which is used in [railways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Railways "Railways"), [skyscrapers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skyscraper "Skyscraper") and many other products.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-398) This coincided with the [Industrial Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution"), where the invention of automated machines brought major changes to humans' lifestyles.[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-399) Modern technology is observed as [progressing exponentially](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accelerating_change "Accelerating change"),[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-400) with major innovations in the 20th century including: [electricity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electricity_generation "Electricity generation"), [penicillin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penicillin "Penicillin"), [semiconductors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semiconductor "Semiconductor"), [internal combustion engines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion engine"), the [Internet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet "Internet"), [nitrogen fixing fertilizers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fertilizer "Fertilizer"), [airplanes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airplane "Airplane"), [computers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer "Computer"), [automobiles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car "Car"), [contraceptive pills](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combined_oral_contraceptive_pill "Combined oral contraceptive pill"), [nuclear fission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_fission "Nuclear fission"), the [green revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Revolution "Green Revolution"), [radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio "Radio"), scientific [plant breeding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_breeding "Plant breeding"), [rockets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocket "Rocket"), [air conditioning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_conditioning "Air conditioning"), [television](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television "Television") and the [assembly line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assembly_line "Assembly line").[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-401)

triples.sentence: The [SCMaglev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SCMaglev "SCMaglev"), the [fastest train](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_speed_record_for_rail_vehicles "Land speed record for rail vehicles") in the world clocking in at 603 km/h (375 mph) as of 2015[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-390)
triples.statement: As of 2015, the SCMaglev was the world's fastest train, reaching a speed of 603 km/h (375 mph).

triples.sentence: Stone tools were used by proto-humans at least 2.5 million years ago.[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-391)
triples.statement: Proto-humans used stone tools at least 2.5 million years ago.

triples.sentence: The use and manufacture of tools has been put forward as the ability that defines humans more than anything else[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Choi-2009-392) and has historically been seen as an important evolutionary step.[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-393)
triples.statement: The use and manufacture of tools has been proposed as the defining ability of humans and is historically viewed as a significant evolutionary step.

triples.sentence: The technology became much more sophisticated about 1.8 million years ago,[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Choi-2009-392) with the [controlled use of fire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_of_fire_by_early_humans "Control of fire by early humans") beginning around 1 million years ago.[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-394)[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-395)
triples.statement: Technology became more sophisticated about 1.8 million years ago, and the controlled use of fire began around 1 million years ago.

triples.sentence: The wheel and wheeled vehicles appeared simultaneously in several regions some time in the fourth millennium BC.[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Bodn%C3%A1r-2018-65)
triples.statement: The wheel and wheeled vehicles appeared in several regions around the same time during the fourth millennium BC.

triples.sentence: The development of more complex tools and technologies allowed land to be [cultivated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arable_land "Arable land") and animals to be [domesticated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestication "Domestication"), thus proving essential in the development of [agriculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agriculture "Agriculture")– what is known as the [Neolithic Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neolithic_Revolution "Neolithic Revolution").[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-396)
triples.statement: The development of more complex tools and technologies, which enabled land cultivation and animal domestication, was essential to the development of agriculture during the Neolithic Revolution.

triples.sentence: [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China "China") developed [paper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paper "Paper"), the [printing press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Printing_press "Printing press"), [gunpowder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunpowder "Gunpowder"), the [compass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compass "Compass") and [other important inventions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Chinese_inventions "List of Chinese inventions").[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-397)
triples.statement: China developed paper, the printing press, gunpowder, the compass, and other significant inventions.

triples.sentence: The continued improvements in [smelting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smelting "Smelting") allowed [forging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forging "Forging") of copper, bronze, iron and eventually [steel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steel "Steel"), which is used in [railways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Railways "Railways"), [skyscrapers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skyscraper "Skyscraper") and many other products.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-398)
triples.statement: Improvements in smelting enabled the forging of metals like copper, bronze, iron, and eventually steel, which is used in railways, skyscrapers, and other products.

triples.sentence: Modern technology is observed as [progressing exponentially](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accelerating_change "Accelerating change"),[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-400) with major innovations in the 20th century including: [electricity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electricity_generation "Electricity generation"), [penicillin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penicillin "Penicillin"), [semiconductors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semiconductor "Semiconductor"), [internal combustion engines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion engine"), the [Internet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet "Internet"), [nitrogen fixing fertilizers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fertilizer "Fertilizer"), [airplanes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airplane "Airplane"), [computers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer "Computer"), [automobiles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car "Car"), [contraceptive pills](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combined_oral_contraceptive_pill "Combined oral contraceptive pill"), [nuclear fission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_fission "Nuclear fission"), the [green revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Revolution "Green Revolution"), [radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio "Radio"), scientific [plant breeding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_breeding "Plant breeding"), [rockets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocket "Rocket"), [air conditioning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_conditioning "Air conditioning"), [television](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television "Television") and the [assembly line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assembly_line "Assembly line").[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-401)
triples.statement: Modern technology is seen as progressing exponentially, with major 20th-century innovations including electricity, penicillin, semiconductors, the internet, airplanes, computers, and many others.

section_body:
Main articles: [Religion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religion "Religion") and [Spirituality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spirituality "Spirituality")

[![Image 40](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Brooklyn_Museum_1992.133.4_Figure_of_Shango_on_Horseback.jpg/250px-Brooklyn_Museum_1992.133.4_Figure_of_Shango_on_Horseback.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Brooklyn_Museum_1992.133.4_Figure_of_Shango_on_Horseback.jpg)

[Shango](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shango "Shango"), the [Orisha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orisha "Orisha") of fire, lightning, and thunder, in the [Yoruba religion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoruba_religion "Yoruba religion"), depicted on horseback

[Definitions of religion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Definition_of_religion "Definition of religion") vary;[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Idinopulos-1998-402) according to one definition, a religion is a [belief](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief "Belief") system concerning the [supernatural](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supernatural "Supernatural"), [sacred](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred "Sacred") or [divine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divinity "Divinity"), and practices, [values](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Values "Values"), institutions and [rituals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ritual "Ritual") associated with such belief. Some religions also have a [moral code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_code "Moral code"). The [evolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology_of_religion "Evolutionary psychology of religion") and the history of the [first religions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_origin_of_religions "Evolutionary origin of religions") have become areas of active scientific investigation.[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-403)[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-404)[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-405) Credible evidence of religious behaviour dates to the [Middle Paleolithic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_Paleolithic "Middle Paleolithic") era (45–200 [thousand years ago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tya_(unit) "Tya (unit)")).[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-406) It may have evolved to play a role in helping enforce and encourage cooperation between humans.[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-407)

Religion manifests in diverse forms.[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Idinopulos-1998-402) Religion can include a belief in [life after death](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_after_death "Life after death"),[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-408) the [origin of life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Origin_of_life "Origin of life"), the nature of the [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe "Universe") ([religious cosmology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_cosmology "Religious cosmology")) and its [ultimate fate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultimate_fate "Ultimate fate") ([eschatology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eschatology "Eschatology")), and [moral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morality "Morality") or [ethical teachings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_ethics "Religious ethics").[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-409) Views on [transcendence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transcendence_(religion) "Transcendence (religion)") and [immanence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immanence "Immanence") vary substantially; traditions variously espouse [monism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monism "Monism"), [deism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deism "Deism"), [pantheism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pantheism "Pantheism"), and [theism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theism "Theism") (including [polytheism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polytheism "Polytheism") and [monotheism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monotheism "Monotheism")).[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-410)

Although measuring religiosity is difficult,[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-411) a majority of humans profess some variety of religious or spiritual belief.[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-412) In 2015 the plurality were [Christian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christians "Christians") followed by [Muslims](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslims "Muslims"), [Hindus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindus "Hindus") and [Buddhists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism").[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-413) As of 2015, about 16%, or slightly under 1.2 billion humans, were [irreligious](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irreligious "Irreligious"), including those with no religious beliefs or no identity with any religion.[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-414)

triples.sentence: It may have evolved to play a role in helping enforce and encourage cooperation between humans.[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-407)
triples.statement: Religion may have evolved to help enforce and encourage cooperation between humans.

triples.sentence: Although measuring religiosity is difficult,[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-411) a majority of humans profess some variety of religious or spiritual belief.[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-412)
triples.statement: Although measuring religiosity is difficult, a majority of humans profess some variety of religious or spiritual belief.

triples.sentence: In 2015 the plurality were [Christian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christians "Christians") followed by [Muslims](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslims "Muslims"), [Hindus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindus "Hindus") and [Buddhists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism").[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-413)
triples.statement: In 2015, the largest religious group was Christians, followed by Muslims, Hindus, and Buddhists.

triples.sentence: As of 2015, about 16%, or slightly under 1.2 billion humans, were [irreligious](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irreligious "Irreligious"), including those with no religious beliefs or no identity with any religion.[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-414)
triples.statement: As of 2015, about 16% of humans, or slightly under 1.2 billion, were irreligious, having no religious beliefs or identity.

section_body:
Main articles: [Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science "Science") and [Philosophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy "Philosophy")

[![Image 41](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Dunhuang_star_map.jpg/250px-Dunhuang_star_map.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Dunhuang_star_map.jpg)

The [Dunhuang map](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunhuang_map "Dunhuang map"), a [star map](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_map "Star map") showing the North Polar region. China circa 700.

An aspect unique to humans is their ability to [transmit knowledge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_transfer "Knowledge transfer") from one generation to the next and to continually build on this information to develop tools, [scientific laws](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_law "Scientific law") and other advances to pass on further.[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-415) This accumulated knowledge can be tested to answer questions or make predictions about how the universe functions and has been very successful in advancing human ascendancy.[[413]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-416)

[Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle "Aristotle") has been described as the first scientist,[[414]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-417) and preceded the rise of scientific thought through the [Hellenistic period](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hellenistic_period "Hellenistic period").[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-418) Other early advances in science came from the [Han dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_and_technology_of_the_Han_dynasty "Science and technology of the Han dynasty") in China and during the [Islamic Golden Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age "Islamic Golden Age").[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-419)[[91]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Renima-2016-91) The [scientific revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_Revolution "Scientific Revolution"), near the end of the [Renaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance"), led to the emergence of [modern science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_science "Modern science").[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-420)

A chain of events and influences led to the development of the [scientific method](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_method "Scientific method"), a process of observation and experimentation that is used to differentiate science from [pseudoscience](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudoscience "Pseudoscience").[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-421) An understanding of [mathematics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics "Mathematics") is unique to humans, although other species of animals have some [numerical cognition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numerical_cognition "Numerical cognition").[[419]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-422) All of science can be divided into three major branches, the [formal sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_sciences "Formal sciences") (e.g., [logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic "Logic") and [mathematics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics "Mathematics")), which are concerned with [formal systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_systems "Formal systems"), the [applied sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applied_sciences "Applied sciences") (e.g., engineering, medicine), which are focused on practical applications, and the empirical sciences, which are based on [empirical observation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empirical_observation "Empirical observation") and are in turn divided into [natural sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_sciences "Natural sciences") (e.g., [physics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physics "Physics"), [chemistry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemistry "Chemistry"), [biology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biology "Biology")) and [social sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_sciences "Social sciences") (e.g., [psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology "Psychology"), economics, sociology).[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-423)

Philosophy is a field of study where humans seek to understand fundamental truths about themselves and the world in which they live.[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-424) Philosophical inquiry has been a major feature in the development of humans' intellectual history.[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-425) It has been described as the "no man's land" between definitive scientific knowledge and dogmatic religious teachings.[[423]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-426) Major fields of philosophy include [metaphysics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaphysics "Metaphysics"), [epistemology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology "Epistemology"), [logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_(philosophy) "Logic (philosophy)"), and [axiology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axiology "Axiology") (which includes [ethics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics "Ethics") and [aesthetics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aesthetics "Aesthetics")).[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-427)

triples.sentence: An aspect unique to humans is their ability to [transmit knowledge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_transfer "Knowledge transfer") from one generation to the next and to continually build on this information to develop tools, [scientific laws](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_law "Scientific law") and other advances to pass on further.[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-415)
triples.statement: A unique aspect of humans is their ability to transmit knowledge between generations, continually building on it to develop tools, scientific laws, and other advances.

triples.sentence: This accumulated knowledge can be tested to answer questions or make predictions about how the universe functions and has been very successful in advancing human ascendancy.[[413]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-416)
triples.statement: Accumulated knowledge can be tested to answer questions or make predictions about the universe's functions, which has been successful in advancing human ascendancy.

triples.sentence: Other early advances in science came from the [Han dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_and_technology_of_the_Han_dynasty "Science and technology of the Han dynasty") in China and during the [Islamic Golden Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age "Islamic Golden Age").[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-419)[[91]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Renima-2016-91)
triples.statement: Other early scientific advances occurred in China during the Han dynasty and during the Islamic Golden Age.

triples.sentence: The [scientific revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_Revolution "Scientific Revolution"), near the end of the [Renaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance"), led to the emergence of [modern science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_science "Modern science").[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-420)
triples.statement: The scientific revolution, which occurred near the end of the Renaissance, led to the emergence of modern science.

triples.sentence: A chain of events and influences led to the development of the [scientific method](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_method "Scientific method"), a process of observation and experimentation that is used to differentiate science from [pseudoscience](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudoscience "Pseudoscience").[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-421)
triples.statement: A series of events and influences resulted in the development of the scientific method, a process of observation and experimentation used to distinguish science from pseudoscience.

triples.sentence: All of science can be divided into three major branches, the [formal sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_sciences "Formal sciences") (e.g., [logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic "Logic") and [mathematics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics "Mathematics")), which are concerned with [formal systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_systems "Formal systems"), the [applied sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applied_sciences "Applied sciences") (e.g., engineering, medicine), which are focused on practical applications, and the empirical sciences, which are based on [empirical observation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empirical_observation "Empirical observation") and are in turn divided into [natural sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_sciences "Natural sciences") (e.g., [physics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physics "Physics"), [chemistry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemistry "Chemistry"), [biology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biology "Biology")) and [social sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_sciences "Social sciences") (e.g., [psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology "Psychology"), economics, sociology).[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-423)
triples.statement: Science can be divided into three major branches: formal sciences (like logic and mathematics), applied sciences (like engineering and medicine), and empirical sciences, which are further divided into natural and social sciences.

triples.sentence: Philosophy is a field of study where humans seek to understand fundamental truths about themselves and the world in which they live.[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-424)
triples.statement: Philosophy is a field of study in which humans seek to understand fundamental truths about themselves and their world.

triples.sentence: Philosophical inquiry has been a major feature in the development of humans' intellectual history.[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-425)
triples.statement: Philosophical inquiry has been a significant feature in the development of human intellectual history.

section_body:
Main article: [Society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society "Society")

[![Image 42](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Indian_family_in_Brazil_posed_in_front_of_hut.jpg/250px-Indian_family_in_Brazil_posed_in_front_of_hut.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Indian_family_in_Brazil_posed_in_front_of_hut.jpg)

Humans often live in family-based social structures.

Society is the system of organizations and institutions arising from interaction between humans. Humans are highly social and tend to live in large complex social groups. They can be divided into different groups according to their income, wealth, [power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_(social_and_political) "Power (social and political)"), [reputation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reputation "Reputation") and other factors. The structure of [social stratification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_stratification "Social stratification") and the degree of [social mobility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_mobility "Social mobility") differs, especially between modern and traditional societies.[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-428) Human groups range from the size of [families](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family "Family") to nations. The first form of human social organization is thought to have resembled [hunter-gatherer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter-gatherer "Hunter-gatherer")[band societies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Band_society "Band society").[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-429)

triples.sentence: The structure of [social stratification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_stratification "Social stratification") and the degree of [social mobility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_mobility "Social mobility") differs, especially between modern and traditional societies.[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-428)
triples.statement: The structure of social stratification and the degree of social mobility vary, particularly between modern and traditional societies.

triples.sentence: The first form of human social organization is thought to have resembled [hunter-gatherer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter-gatherer "Hunter-gatherer")[band societies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Band_society "Band society").[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-429)
triples.statement: The earliest form of human social organization is believed to have been similar to hunter-gatherer band societies.

section_body:
Main article: [Gender](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender "Gender")

[![Image 43](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Human.svg/250px-Human.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Human.svg)

Depiction of a [man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man "Man") and a [woman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woman "Woman") from the [Pioneer plaque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_plaque "Pioneer plaque")

Human societies typically exhibit [gender identities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_identity "Gender identity") and [gender roles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_role "Gender role") that distinguish between [masculine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masculinity "Masculinity") and [feminine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Femininity "Femininity") characteristics and prescribe the range of acceptable behaviours and attitudes for their members based on their sex.[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-430)[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-431) The most common categorisation is a [gender binary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_binary "Gender binary") of [men](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men "Men") and [women](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women "Women").[[429]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-432) Some societies recognize a [third gender](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_gender "Third gender"),[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-433) or less commonly a fourth or fifth.[[431]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-434)[[432]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-435) In some other societies, [non-binary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-binary_gender "Non-binary gender") is used as an umbrella term for a range of gender identities that are not solely male or female.[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-436)

Gender roles are often associated with a division of [norms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_norm "Social norm"), [practices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Practice_(social_theory) "Practice (social theory)"), [dress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clothing "Clothing"), [behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_behavior "Social behavior"), [rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rights "Rights"), [duties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duty "Duty"), [privileges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Privilege_(social_inequality) "Privilege (social inequality)"), [status](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_status "Social status"), and [power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_(social_and_political) "Power (social and political)"), with men enjoying more rights and privileges than women in most societies, both today and in the past.[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-437) As a [social construct](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_constructionism "Social constructionism"),[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-438) gender roles are not fixed and vary historically within a society. Challenges to predominant gender norms have recurred in many societies.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-439)[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-440) Little is known about gender roles in the earliest human societies. [Early modern humans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Early_modern_human "Early modern human") probably had a range of gender roles similar to that of modern cultures from at least the [Upper Paleolithic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic "Upper Paleolithic"), while the Neanderthals were less sexually dimorphic and there is evidence that the behavioural difference between males and females was minimal.[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-441)

triples.sentence: In some other societies, [non-binary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-binary_gender "Non-binary gender") is used as an umbrella term for a range of gender identities that are not solely male or female.[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-436)
triples.statement: In some societies, 'non-binary' is an umbrella term for gender identities that are not exclusively male or female.

triples.sentence: Gender roles are often associated with a division of [norms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_norm "Social norm"), [practices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Practice_(social_theory) "Practice (social theory)"), [dress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clothing "Clothing"), [behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_behavior "Social behavior"), [rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rights "Rights"), [duties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duty "Duty"), [privileges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Privilege_(social_inequality) "Privilege (social inequality)"), [status](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_status "Social status"), and [power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_(social_and_political) "Power (social and political)"), with men enjoying more rights and privileges than women in most societies, both today and in the past.[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-437)
triples.statement: Gender roles are often linked to divisions of norms, practices, dress, behavior, rights, duties, privileges, status, and power, with men having more rights and privileges than women in most societies, both currently and in the past.

triples.sentence: As a [social construct](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_constructionism "Social constructionism"),[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-438) gender roles are not fixed and vary historically within a society.
triples.statement: As a social construct, gender roles are not fixed and vary historically within a society.

section_body:
Main article: [Kinship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinship "Kinship")

All human societies organize, recognize and classify types of social relationships based on relations between parents, children and other descendants ([consanguinity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consanguinity "Consanguinity")), and relations through [marriage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marriage "Marriage") ([affinity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affinity_(law) "Affinity (law)")). There is also a third type applied to [godparents](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Godparent "Godparent") or [adoptive children](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adoption "Adoption") ([fictive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fictive_kinship "Fictive kinship")). These culturally defined relationships are referred to as kinship. In many societies, it is one of the most important social organizing principles and plays a role in transmitting status and [inheritance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inheritance "Inheritance").[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-442)All societies have rules of [incest taboo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incest_taboo "Incest taboo"), according to which marriage between certain kinds of kin relations is prohibited, and some also have rules of preferential marriage with certain kin relations.[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-443)

Pair bonding is a ubiquitous feature of human sexual relationships, whether it is manifested as serial monogamy, [polygyny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygyny "Polygyny"), or [polyandry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polyandry "Polyandry").[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-444) Genetic evidence indicates that humans were predominantly [polygynous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygyny "Polygyny") for most of their existence as a species, but that this began to shift during the Neolithic, when [monogamy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monogamy "Monogamy") started becoming widespread concomitantly with the transition from nomadic to sedentary societies.[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-445) Anatomical evidence in the form of second-to-fourth digit ratios, a biomarker for prenatal androgen effects, likewise indicates modern humans were polygynous during the Pleistocene.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-446)

triples.sentence: In many societies, it is one of the most important social organizing principles and plays a role in transmitting status and [inheritance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inheritance "Inheritance").[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-442)
triples.statement: In many societies, kinship is a primary social organizing principle and is involved in transmitting status and inheritance.

triples.sentence: All societies have rules of [incest taboo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incest_taboo "Incest taboo"), according to which marriage between certain kinds of kin relations is prohibited, and some also have rules of preferential marriage with certain kin relations.[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-443)
triples.statement: All societies have incest taboos that prohibit marriage between certain kin, and some also have rules for preferential marriage with specific kin relations.

triples.sentence: Pair bonding is a ubiquitous feature of human sexual relationships, whether it is manifested as serial monogamy, [polygyny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygyny "Polygyny"), or [polyandry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polyandry "Polyandry").[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-444)
triples.statement: Pair bonding is a common feature of human sexual relationships, manifesting as serial monogamy, polygyny, or polyandry.

triples.sentence: Genetic evidence indicates that humans were predominantly [polygynous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygyny "Polygyny") for most of their existence as a species, but that this began to shift during the Neolithic, when [monogamy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monogamy "Monogamy") started becoming widespread concomitantly with the transition from nomadic to sedentary societies.[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-445)
triples.statement: Genetic evidence suggests that humans were predominantly polygynous for most of their existence, shifting towards monogamy during the Neolithic as societies transitioned from nomadic to sedentary lifestyles.

triples.sentence: Anatomical evidence in the form of second-to-fourth digit ratios, a biomarker for prenatal androgen effects, likewise indicates modern humans were polygynous during the Pleistocene.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-446)
triples.statement: Anatomical evidence from second-to-fourth digit ratios, a biomarker for prenatal androgen effects, also indicates that modern humans were polygynous during the Pleistocene.

section_body:
Main article: [Ethnic group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_group "Ethnic group")

Human ethnic groups are a social category that [identifies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_(social_science) "Identity (social science)") together as a group based on shared attributes that distinguish them from other groups. These can be a common set of traditions, [ancestry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancestry "Ancestry"), [language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language "Language"), [history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History "History"), [society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society "Society"), [culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture "Culture"), [nation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nation "Nation"), [religion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religion "Religion"), or social treatment within their residing area.[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-447)[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-448) Ethnicity is separate from the concept of [race](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_(human_categorization) "Race (human categorization)"), which is based on physical characteristics, although both are [socially constructed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_constructionism "Social constructionism").[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-449) Assigning ethnicity to a certain population is complicated, as even within common ethnic designations there can be a diverse range of subgroups, and the makeup of these ethnic groups can change over time at both the collective and individual level.[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-REGWG2005-181) Also, there is no generally accepted definition of what constitutes an ethnic group.[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-450) Ethnic groupings can play a powerful role in the [social identity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_identity "Social identity") and solidarity of ethnopolitical units. This has been closely tied to the rise of the [nation state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nation_state "Nation state") as the predominant form of political organization in the 19th and 20th centuries.[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-451)[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-452)[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-453)

triples.sentence: Ethnicity is separate from the concept of [race](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_(human_categorization) "Race (human categorization)"), which is based on physical characteristics, although both are [socially constructed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_constructionism "Social constructionism").[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-449)
triples.statement: Ethnicity is distinct from the concept of race, which is based on physical characteristics, though both are considered socially constructed.

triples.sentence: Assigning ethnicity to a certain population is complicated, as even within common ethnic designations there can be a diverse range of subgroups, and the makeup of these ethnic groups can change over time at both the collective and individual level.[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-REGWG2005-181)
triples.statement: Assigning ethnicity to a population is complex, as common ethnic designations can contain diverse subgroups, and the composition of these groups can change over time.

section_body:
Main articles: [Government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government "Government") and [Politics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics "Politics")

[![Image 44](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/United_Nations_Headquarters_in_New_York_City%2C_view_from_Roosevelt_Island.jpg/250px-United_Nations_Headquarters_in_New_York_City%2C_view_from_Roosevelt_Island.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:United_Nations_Headquarters_in_New_York_City,_view_from_Roosevelt_Island.jpg)

The [United Nations headquarters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations "Headquarters of the United Nations") (left) in New York City, which houses one of the world's largest political organizations

As farming populations gathered in larger and denser communities, interactions between these different groups increased. This led to the development of governance within and between the communities.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-454) Humans have evolved the ability to change affiliation with various social groups relatively easily, including previously strong political alliances, if doing so is seen as providing personal advantages.[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-455) This [cognitive flexibility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_flexibility "Cognitive flexibility") allows individual humans to change their political ideologies, with those with higher flexibility less likely to support authoritarian and nationalistic stances.[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-456)

Governments create [laws](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law "Law") and [policies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Policies "Policies") that affect the citizens that they govern. There have been [many forms of government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_forms_of_government "List of forms of government") throughout human history, each having various means of obtaining power and the ability to exert diverse controls on the population.[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-457) Approximately 47% of humans live in some form of a [democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democracy "Democracy"), 17% in a [hybrid regime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_regime "Hybrid regime"), and 37% in an [authoritarian regime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_regime "Authoritarian regime").[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-458) Many countries belong to [international organizations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_organization "International organization") and [alliances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alliances "Alliances"); the largest of these is the [United Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations"), with [193 member states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations "Member states of the United Nations").[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-459)

triples.sentence: This led to the development of governance within and between the communities.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-454)
triples.statement: Increased interaction between farming communities led to the development of governance.

triples.sentence: This [cognitive flexibility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_flexibility "Cognitive flexibility") allows individual humans to change their political ideologies, with those with higher flexibility less likely to support authoritarian and nationalistic stances.[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-456)
triples.statement: Cognitive flexibility allows individual humans to change their political ideologies, and those with higher flexibility are less likely to support authoritarian and nationalistic stances.

triples.sentence: There have been [many forms of government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_forms_of_government "List of forms of government") throughout human history, each having various means of obtaining power and the ability to exert diverse controls on the population.[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-457)
triples.statement: Throughout human history, there have been many forms of government, each with different ways of obtaining power and controlling the population.

triples.sentence: Approximately 47% of humans live in some form of a [democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democracy "Democracy"), 17% in a [hybrid regime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_regime "Hybrid regime"), and 37% in an [authoritarian regime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_regime "Authoritarian regime").[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-458)
triples.statement: Approximately 47% of humans live in a democracy, 17% in a hybrid regime, and 37% in an authoritarian regime.

section_body:
Main articles: [Trade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade "Trade") and [Economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economics "Economics")

[![Image 45](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Silk_route.jpg/330px-Silk_route.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Silk_route.jpg)

The [Silk Road](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silk_Road "Silk Road") (red) and spice [trade routes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade_routes "Trade routes") (blue)

Trade, the voluntary exchange of goods and services, is seen as a characteristic that differentiates humans from other animals and has been cited as a practice that gave _Homo sapiens_ a major advantage over other hominids.[[457]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-460) Evidence suggests early _H. sapiens_ made use of long-distance trade routes to exchange goods and ideas, leading to [cultural explosions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_explosion "Cultural explosion") and providing additional food sources when hunting was sparse, while such trade networks did not exist for the now extinct Neanderthals.[[458]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-461)[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-462) Early trade likely involved materials for creating tools like [obsidian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obsidian "Obsidian").[[460]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-463) The first truly international trade routes were around the [spice trade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spice_trade "Spice trade") through the Roman and medieval periods.[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-464)

Early human [economies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy "Economy") were more likely to be based around [gift giving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gift_economy "Gift economy") instead of a [bartering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barter "Barter") system.[[462]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-465) Early [money](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Money "Money") consisted of [commodities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commodity_money "Commodity money"); the oldest being in the form of cattle and the most widely used being [cowrie shells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cowrie_shells "Cowrie shells").[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-www.pbs.org-1996-466) Money has since evolved into governmental issued [coins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coins "Coins"), [paper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paper_money "Paper money") and [electronic money](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_money "Electronic money").[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-www.pbs.org-1996-466) Human study of economics is a [social science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_science "Social science") that looks at how societies distribute scarce resources among different people.[[464]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-467) There are massive [inequalities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality "Economic inequality") in the division of [wealth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth "Wealth") among humans; the eight richest humans are worth the same monetary value as the poorest half of all the human population.[[465]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-468)

triples.sentence: Evidence suggests early _H. sapiens_ made use of long-distance trade routes to exchange goods and ideas, leading to [cultural explosions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_explosion "Cultural explosion") and providing additional food sources when hunting was sparse, while such trade networks did not exist for the now extinct Neanderthals.[[458]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-461)[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-462)
triples.statement: Evidence suggests early H. sapiens utilized long-distance trade routes to exchange goods and ideas, which led to cultural explosions and provided extra food sources, whereas such networks did not exist for the extinct Neanderthals.

triples.sentence: The first truly international trade routes were around the [spice trade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spice_trade "Spice trade") through the Roman and medieval periods.[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-464)
triples.statement: The first truly international trade routes were centered on the spice trade during the Roman and medieval periods.

triples.sentence: Early human [economies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy "Economy") were more likely to be based around [gift giving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gift_economy "Gift economy") instead of a [bartering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barter "Barter") system.[[462]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-465)
triples.statement: Early human economies were more likely based on gift giving rather than a bartering system.

triples.sentence: Early [money](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Money "Money") consisted of [commodities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commodity_money "Commodity money"); the oldest being in the form of cattle and the most widely used being [cowrie shells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cowrie_shells "Cowrie shells").[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-www.pbs.org-1996-466)
triples.statement: Early money consisted of commodities; the oldest form was cattle and the most widely used was cowrie shells.

triples.sentence: Money has since evolved into governmental issued [coins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coins "Coins"), [paper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paper_money "Paper money") and [electronic money](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_money "Electronic money").[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-www.pbs.org-1996-466)
triples.statement: Money has since evolved into government-issued coins, paper, and electronic money.

triples.sentence: Human study of economics is a [social science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_science "Social science") that looks at how societies distribute scarce resources among different people.[[464]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-467)
triples.statement: The human study of economics is a social science that examines how societies distribute scarce resources among different people.

triples.sentence: There are massive [inequalities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality "Economic inequality") in the division of [wealth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth "Wealth") among humans; the eight richest humans are worth the same monetary value as the poorest half of all the human population.[[465]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-468)
triples.statement: There are massive inequalities in the division of wealth among humans; the eight richest humans have a monetary value equal to that of the poorest half of the entire human population.

section_body:
Main article: [Conflict (process)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conflict_(process) "Conflict (process)")

Further information: [Violent crime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Violent_crime "Violent crime") and [War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War "War")

[![Image 46](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Into_the_Jaws_of_Death_23-0455M_edit.jpg/250px-Into_the_Jaws_of_Death_23-0455M_edit.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Into_the_Jaws_of_Death_23-0455M_edit.jpg)

American troops [landing at Normandy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normandy_landings "Normandy landings"), WWII

Humans commit violence on other humans at a rate comparable to other primates, but have an increased preference for killing adults, [infanticide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infanticide_(zoology) "Infanticide (zoology)") being more common among other primates.[[466]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-469) Phylogenetic analysis predicts that 2% of early _H. sapiens_ would be [murdered](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murder "Murder"), rising to 12% during the medieval period, before dropping to below 2% in modern times.[[467]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-470) There is great variation in violence between human populations, with rates of homicide about 0.01% in societies that have [legal systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_national_legal_systems "List of national legal systems") and strong cultural attitudes against violence.[[468]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-471)

The willingness of humans to kill other members of their species en masse through organized conflict (i.e., [war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War "War")) has long been the subject of debate. One school of thought holds that war evolved as a means to eliminate competitors, and has always been an innate human characteristic. Another suggests that war is a relatively recent phenomenon and has appeared due to changing social conditions.[[469]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Ferguson-2018-472) While not settled, current evidence indicates warlike predispositions only became common about 10,000 years ago, and in many places much more recently than that.[[469]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Ferguson-2018-472) War has had a high cost on human life; it is estimated that during the 20th century, between 167 million and 188 million people died as a result of war.[[470]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-473) War casualty data is less reliable for pre-medieval times, especially global figures. But compared with any period over the past 600 years, the last 80 years (post 1946) has seen a very significant drop in global military and civilian death rates due to armed conflict.[[471]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-474)

triples.sentence: Humans commit violence on other humans at a rate comparable to other primates, but have an increased preference for killing adults, [infanticide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infanticide_(zoology) "Infanticide (zoology)") being more common among other primates.[[466]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-469)
triples.statement: The rate of violence among humans is comparable to other primates, but humans show a greater preference for killing adults, whereas infanticide is more common in other primates.

triples.sentence: Phylogenetic analysis predicts that 2% of early _H. sapiens_ would be [murdered](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murder "Murder"), rising to 12% during the medieval period, before dropping to below 2% in modern times.[[467]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-470)
triples.statement: Phylogenetic analysis predicts that the murder rate for early H. sapiens was 2%, rose to 12% in the medieval period, and fell to below 2% in modern times.

triples.sentence: There is great variation in violence between human populations, with rates of homicide about 0.01% in societies that have [legal systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_national_legal_systems "List of national legal systems") and strong cultural attitudes against violence.[[468]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-471)
triples.statement: Violence varies greatly among human populations, with homicide rates around 0.01% in societies with legal systems and strong cultural opposition to violence.

triples.sentence: Another suggests that war is a relatively recent phenomenon and has appeared due to changing social conditions.[[469]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Ferguson-2018-472)
triples.statement: An alternative theory proposes that war is a recent phenomenon resulting from changing social conditions.

triples.sentence: While not settled, current evidence indicates warlike predispositions only became common about 10,000 years ago, and in many places much more recently than that.[[469]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-Ferguson-2018-472)
triples.statement: Current evidence suggests that warlike predispositions became common only about 10,000 years ago, and even more recently in many areas.

triples.sentence: War has had a high cost on human life; it is estimated that during the 20th century, between 167 million and 188 million people died as a result of war.[[470]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-473)
triples.statement: An estimated 167 to 188 million people died due to war during the 20th century.

triples.sentence: But compared with any period over the past 600 years, the last 80 years (post 1946) has seen a very significant drop in global military and civilian death rates due to armed conflict.[[471]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human#cite_note-474)
triples.statement: In the last 80 years (since 1946), global death rates from armed conflict have dropped significantly compared to any period in the previous 600 years.
